message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ocular symptoms in this patient suggest cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis, which commonly occurs in immunocompromised individuals such as those with HIV. The drug of choice for treating CMV retinitis is ganciclovir, a guanosine analog that inhibits viral DNA polymerase. Option A refers to maraviroc, a drug used to block CCR5 receptor to prevent HIV entry into cells. Option C refers to oseltamivir, used to treat influenza by inhibiting neuraminidase. Option D refers to amantadine, used to treat influenza A by inhibiting viral uncoating.

The ocular symptoms suggest cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis which is a common opportunistic infection in HIV positive individuals with low CD4 counts. Guanosine analogs, such as ganciclovir, inhibit viral DNA polymerase and are used to treat CMV retinitis. Option (A) refers to a class of drugs called CCR5 inhibitors used to prevent viral entry into host cells in HIV treatment. Option (C) refers to drugs used to treat influenza by stopping the release of viral progeny. Option (D) refers to drugs used to treat herpes by preventing the uncoating of the virus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ocular symptoms, crackles in all lobes, and positive HIV test suggest that the patient has AIDS-related complex. The drug that can be given to treat the ocular symptoms is ganciclovir, which is a guanosine analog that selectively inhibits viral DNA polymerase. It is used to treat cytomegalovirus retinitis, a common manifestation of AIDS-related complex.

The drug that can be given to treat the ocular symptoms is guanosine analog that preferably inhibits viral DNA polymerase, which is used for the treatment of cytomegalovirus retinopathy in immunocompromised patients. None of the other options are effective for this condition.

The drug that can be given to treat the ocular symptoms is a guanosine analog that preferably inhibits viral DNA polymerase. This drug is called ganciclovir and is used to treat CMV retinitis. Option (A) refers to a drug used to treat HIV itself by blocking the CCR5 receptor. Option (C) refers to a drug that inhibits the influenza virus, not CMV. Option (D) refers to a drug that prevents the entry of the influenza virus into host cells, not CMV.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and history suggest that the patient has HIV-associated cytomegalovirus retinitis. Among the options, only guanosine analogs, such as ganciclovir and valganciclovir, can inhibit viral DNA polymerase and therefore help treat the ocular symptoms. Blocking the CCR5 receptor (option A) is used to treat HIV, neuraminidase inhibitors (option C) are used to treat influenza, and drugs that prevent viral uncoating (option D) are used to treat hepatitis B and C.

Guanosine analogs are used to treat Pneumocystis pneumonia by inhibiting DNA synthesis in the organism. The other options are not relevant to the treatment of Pneumocystis pneumonia.

The drug that can be given to treat the ocular symptoms is ganciclovir, which is a guanosine analog that inhibits viral DNA polymerase, preventing viral replication. Option A refers to HIV-specific drugs, Option C refers to influenza-specific drugs, and Option D refers to drugs that treat hepatitis B virus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ocular symptoms, along with a positive rapid HIV test, suggest that the patient has cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis. The drug of choice for treating CMV retinitis is ganciclovir, which is a guanosine analog that inhibits viral DNA polymerase. Therefore, option (B) is the correct answer. Option (A) refers to maraviroc, which is a drug used in the treatment of HIV, but it does not treat symptoms of CMV retinitis. Option (C) refers to oseltamivir, which is a drug used to treat influenza virus infections. Option (D) refers to amantadine and rimantadine, which are drugs used to treat influenza A virus infections, but they do not treat symptoms of CMV retinitis.
